Award.AwardTitle: FSML: Improving the Detection, Enumeration and Visualization of Aquatic Microorganisms at the Romberg Tiburon Center, SFSU
Award.AbstractNarration:
San Francisco State University (SFSU) has been awarded a grant to significantly increase their capabilities to visualize, characterize and enumerate marine microorganisms in their research and educational efforts at the Romberg Tiburon Center for Environmental Studies (RTC), an off-campus marine research and teaching facility. The grant will increase RTC's analytical capabilities for microbial research by the purchase of two major instruments: 1) a state-of-the-art inverted, epifluorescence microscope (Olympus model IX81) equipped with differential interference contrast (Nomarski) prisms and a high-definition digital imaging and analysis system, and 2) a user-friendly and easy-to-maintain flow cytometer (BD Biosciences Accuri C-6). The requested microscope will replace older, joint-use and private microscopes that are of lesser optical performance, and lack the capability for image capture and interpretation. The flow cytometer will permit timely quantification and characterization of both natural and cultured phytoplankton and bacteria, and microbial assemblages. Due to its relative simplicity and compact design, the instrument will be employed in both laboratory and at-sea research investigations.

The broader impacts of the new instrumentation are through contributions that bridge interdisciplinary and institutional boundaries. Collaborative RTC research efforts involving investigators from other universities, and both federal and state agencies will benefit from the improvements and increased functionality provided by these instruments in quantifying and characterizing planktonic systems currently under study, including multi-disciplinary studies in San Francisco Bay, the tropical Atlantic Ocean and the Pacific Northwest. Digital video and imagery from the microscope platform will be available for use by RTC's Outreach Coordinator to share research content with the general public, and for use in local educational efforts. The RTC investigators expected to utilize the two instruments are actively engaged in graduate and undergraduate instruction, and although the microscope and flow cytometer will be used primarily for research purposes it is expected that that both instruments will be utilized in the training of SFSU graduate and undergraduate students. For further information about the center please visit its website at http://rtc.sfsu.edu/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Modern oceanographic facilities require instrumentation for accurate, precise and timely quantification of the microorganisms that define aquatic food chains, and a means to characterize their ecological role in marine and estuarine systems. Approximately half of the principal investigators at the Estuary & Ocean Science Center (formerly known as the Romberg Tiburon Center for Environmental Studies) study bacteria, phytoplankton or zooplankton either locally in San Francisco Bay, the surrounding coastal regions of northern California or worldwide, but have been using antiquated microscopic platforms that are unsuitable for today’s research needs. Modern molecular approaches to quantify the abundance and characterize the metabolic activity of aquatic microorganisms using fluorescence microscopy and cytometry have not been pursued by EOS Center scientists due to the lack of these essential tools. The FSML award have rectified this serious analytical problem, and now researchers and educators have been trained in the effective use of two major instruments purchased at the start of this project: 1) a state-of-the-art inverted, epifluorescence microscope (Olympus model IX83) equipped with a high-definition digital imaging and analysis system, and 2) a user-friendly and easy-to-maintain flow cytometer (BD Biosciences Accuri C-6). The new Olympus microscope has replaced the older microscopes that lacked the capability for image capture and were of poorer optical performance. The flow cytometer has allowed for timely quantification and characterization of both natural assemblages and cultured populations of microbial organisms, and due to its relative simplicity and compact design, has been employed not only ashore, but also at sea during oceanographic research cruises.

These two instruments have advanced a variety of EOS Center research activities including: 1) climate change studies to examine how the growth and toxicity of phytoplankton species that form Harmful Algal Blooms (HABs) are impacted by the environmental consequences of climate change, 2) field and laboratory studies to understand the effects of ocean acidification on the nutritional quality of phytoplankton in eastern boundary upwelling systems, 3) estuarine studies to examine the effects of nutrient forms, nutrient ratios and light availability on the lower food web of San Francisco Bay, and 4) zooplankton feeding studies to identify and enumerate the micro- to picoplankton species used as prey for these metazoans.

Broader impacts resulting from the purchase and use of these modern analytical instruments are through contributions that bridge interdisciplinary and institutional boundaries. Institutionally, these instruments have not only been used by EOS Center researchers, but by graduate students and investigators from other universities in the US and Canada, in addition to visiting students and teachers associated with two national programs hosted each summer at the EOS Center: the NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program, and the STEM teacher and researcher (STAR) program. Digital video and imagery from the FSML-purchased microscope have greatly enhanced our ability to communicate scientific findings with the general public. Not only have images and content been used to improve our local, national, and international instructional and training efforts, but they also have been made readily available to web, print, video, and television journalists to better inform the public of the role of estuarine and marine microbes in coastal ecosystems, including during the unprecedented and widespread toxic algal blooms along the west coast of North America in recent years.
